segments.text: This is Martha Hunt interviewing Dr. Ruth Schaefer, November 16, 1985, on women in academia.
Dr. Schaefer, how long have you been teaching at the university level?
Let's see.
Almost 35 years.
35 years.
And how long has that been at A&M?
Where did you go to school for your graduate and undergraduate degrees?
I did my undergraduate degree at Hunter College in New York, and then I received a master's at Penn State and a doctorate at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill.
And what made you decide to become a professor?
Well, I'm not really sure that I ever did decide to become a professor.
When I was a junior or lower senior, I was intrigued by a group of studies that we read in sociology.
these were community studies and I thought it would be fun to make community studies and so I decided to go on in graduate school as a natural course of that interest and make community studies.
Did you feel it was a choice that you had to make between having a family and having a career?
No.
Now, I did have one experience.
I decided just before I graduated from college that I would apply to Gettysburg Seminary to become a Lutheran minister.
And I was rejected.
I don't even know whether there were any Lutheran women clergy at that time.
But my other choice was to go into sociology and become a researcher.
don't think that I even thought.
I just assumed that someday I would meet someone and fall in love and marry and that everything would just fit in.
I never even gave it a moment's thought that this was a choice between one or the other.
When you applied to seminary, do you feel that you were rejected because you were a woman?
Yes.
Oh, yes.
Yes, absolutely.
And in fact, we were talking about this the other day because at the University of North Carolina was a woman who was the first president of the Southern.
She was an officer in the American society.
She wrote many books and was editor of Social Forces, which is one of our major journals.
And she also was Lutheran.
And when she finished her PhD at North Carolina, she applied to teach at a small Lutheran college, and they rejected her.
And then something like 15 years later, they asked her if she would come and teach in a Lutheran college.
By that time, she was one of the top women sociologists in the country.
And I think they wanted to offer her something like $6,000 a year.
Oh, my goodness.
So she rejected it at that time.
But in her case, too, it was the fact that women were just not accepted.
But that didn't mean women were... A church-related school was very different from a state school.
There were...
I went to a women's college on the undergraduate level
So I had a lot of role models probably.
That's why it never dawned on me that one made a choice between a career and marriage because almost all my professors were married and had children and were pursuing their careers as well.
What is your definition of a liberated woman or a feminist?
I'm not sure that I've ever given a great deal of thought.
And I'm not sure that some of the connotations of liberated and feminist, I'm not sure that they're the same.
I think they have different meanings.
I think they have different meanings.
And I think you have to remember that I come from a little bit different tradition than some of the younger women faculty.
And that basically, while I was discriminated against in terms of salary level, I never suffered some of the discrimination that some of the later, that some women
colleagues have suggested that they suffered.
So that I, my position has always been that a woman did deserve, if she was filling a similar position, the same salary levels and same opportunities as men.
I look on this as equality rather than liberation or feminist or so on.

And frankly, one of the problems that I have had early on at Texas A&M and one of the problems that I had in graduate school for a short time was the fact that people differentiate between male and female scientists.
I see.
Well, do you feel that...
You have been, say, following your husband around because he was a sociologist.
Okay, okay.
I taught after I received my master's.
I originally wanted to go straight on after finishing my master's for a doctor.
And I worked under a man who, I guess one of the reasons that,
I didn't recognize a lot of discrimination was I was always very lucky and worked under marvelous people.
And at Penn State I worked under a man named William G. Mather, who at the tender age of late 80s was working very actively in retirement in Florida for women's rights and for the passage of ERA.
While he never discussed any of these areas,
except human rights in general.
He didn't differentiate between women and so on.
He was very active.
He took me on.
He sought me out and offered me the position of his research assistant.
And he is a superb human being.
And so I didn't have that kind of experience.
And I think I've missed your question somewhere there.
Oh, I was just talking about when you came to A&M, when you received a job at A&M, was your husband also?
Oh, the following, okay.
Okay, so I worked first and taught at the University of Rochester after the Masters.
He said, this is not going to be a rural society, and don't go on in rural sociology.
And so he literally forced me, found me a job teaching at the University of Rochester,
when I went home over the Christmas holidays, I came back, I had this job, because he didn't really want me to go on.
And he was right, you know, this is not a rural society.
At that time, I was the only woman member of the, as a graduate student, I was the only female member of the rural sociological society.
So he was very wise.
Okay, so I taught at Rochester for about a year and a half before going on for my doctorate at North Carolina.
And I was, I had made all my own decisions.
Okay.
I met my husband when I was just about finished the doctor.
And he was behind me because he'd been in the service and went back to school after completing longing.
So that when we married, I then literally did follow him.
And I never ever had any problem getting a job.
But he always had the job.
It was never a matter of, it's your turn now, or that kind of thing.
And I recognize that that is partly the case.
But in some respects, because we have had some experience here in attempting to recruit women, I'm not sure that that truly works.
I see.
And the reason I'm not sure, if you're interested in why I'm not sure, is that on several occasions we have offered positions to women who are married.
And we raised the question with them, what happens if we offer you a position and your husband does not get a position in the area?
And their comment was, we will come regardless because it is our turn.
But none of them
when it came down to the nuts and bolts, ever did.
They always went wherever both partners could get a job.
Oh, well, that's very interesting.
So I'm not sure that this works.
Well, when you received a job offer here, or your husband did and you did, was there a discrimination as far as
As far as salary, because he was a man?
When we came, we were finishing up a book.
We came in June instead of waiting until the end of the summer.
And I wrote a letter to all the divisions of the university that I felt might be receptive to a sociologist.
I had had experiences at Alabama where I could teach in the sociology department, but I could only teach one course because my husband was also teaching.
And so a school of social work was developed, and the dean was just a truly outstanding person.

And an old friend of mine had worked with him in Rochester and later in California, so when he was announced that he was to come as the dean of a new school of social work, I contacted him and asked him whether he was interested in employing me.
So I taught research methods and sociological type things in the School of Social Work.
So I was full time, my husband was full time.
When I came here, I didn't think there would be a chance of a job in sociology.
And so I wrote all these letters and different people interviewed me.
One day I went in and was interviewed by a man named Earl Cook, who was
to become dean of geosciences shortly after our interview.
And he employed me part time with a research program that he had.
So I had a considerable number of publications and several books.
And so at that time, Texas A&M was trying to expand its horizon and to upgrade faculty.
It was the beginning of that period.
And so he employed me immediately.
into this program.
And then one week before the beginning of the fall semester, the young man who taught power and community left.
I mean, just left.
And so Dr. Scribonic called me and asked me whether I would come and teach those courses.
And being Dr. Scribonic, he repeated again and again that he did not know whether this would work into a full-time position or, you know, a full-time appointment.
And at that time, Texas had a rule that stated that a husband and wife could not work in the same department, one under the other.
That's interesting.
And in fact, I think that rule still stands.
In other words, if one of us were to become head of a department, I don't think that the other one could work under him.
Because I think Shirley Black and Bryson Gooch had that problem when they married.
In history.
Oh, that's interesting.
Speaking of the publications that you have had, do you feel that you were ever turned down to have something published because you were a woman?
No.
No.
No, I have never had that problem.
Do you feel that you had to work harder to get where you are today than your husband had to?
Do you feel that in school you had to work harder in getting a job because you're a woman?
No.
I never really had very much difficulty, and I guess I've always worked hard.
Did you receive less encouragement for your achievements?
Or were you always encouraged by your parents and your professors and other colleagues?
That's a difficult question.
I'm from a New England family.
And my parents just always had the expectation that I would do well or that I would work hard because in the New England family you work hard in the Protestant ethic and the spirit of capitalism.
My parents were always encouraging.
My mother and father never believed that there wasn't anything.
I mean, it never dawned on me that there would be a problem in a career because one was a woman.
Do you ever feel that male colleagues would avoid you or feel that what you had to say was unimportant?
No.
I don't think so.
I think that that's a complicated question because it doesn't take a few things into consideration.
For example, when I meet a new colleague, male or female, let's say in another department, I don't accept them just because they're another colleague.
I kind of
look them over and I listen to them.
And if I'm going to work with them, I determine what their qualifications are and I assess them.
I think everyone has the right to assess someone that they're going to be working with, male or female.
It doesn't really make any difference.
And so I would expect people to assess me and to use the skills that I have.
just as I use the skills that other people have.
There are several people on campus that I use whenever I need advice or whenever some area comes up that I need special help.
And people use me in the same way.
Did you ever or have you ever experienced sexism from male professors?
I guess it depends on how you define sexism.
When I came to Texas A&M, I had a different experience than I had... Well, that's not true.
I guess, let's go back to Alabama.
I had a superb dean who gave me every opportunity.
I could travel.
There was nothing that I wanted to do that I could not do.
But my salary was low.
Well, I guess at one point,
When I went on to the faculty of the School of Social Work, he asked me, and I was the first faculty member besides him, he asked me what rank I wanted.
And my husband was an associate, and he was coming up for a full professorship.
So I said, and I guess one would interpret this as, well, interpret it any way you wish.
I said, no, let me, my husband's an associate and he's coming up for a full, so give me an associate rank and when he comes up for a full, then bring me up to a full.
So the dean followed through on my wishes.
My salary was less than people he was bringing in to start this new school.
I had more, I worked side by side with him, and I was his chief confidant in the development of the school, and he literally could not have done it without me.
I was also his dean of admissions, and so on and so forth, director of admissions.
Then my husband, within about four or five months, became a full professor.
So I expected that I would become a full professor, and I didn't.
So the following year, I said to my dean, when are you going to make me a full professor?
And he said, well, the time is not right.
And I said, it'll never be righter.
I said, put my name in.
He said, well, I don't think you'll get it.
I said, put my name in.
And so I got it.
And one of the vice presidents who I knew at the university said to the dean, how come you didn't make her a full professor to begin with?
I don't know why the dean did that.
But I think he didn't want to go up on my salary, which you automatically had to do, because he was trying to recruit somebody who was going to come high.
So in a sense, you see, that was discriminating.
While I was not discriminated against in terms of the work, I have always had trouble with salary.
Then here, on a couple of occasions, my salary was low.
And it was kept low.
The only increases I got were when the dean gave it to me.
And when Dr. Gaston came, he started moving my salary up.
But I don't, I think in a strange way, this was not a reflection of my sex.
It was a reflection of the fact that I tended to fight a department head.
for the rights of younger faculty, because we had younger faculty who were not being moved up, and preference being given to others, and so I would go in and fight for them.
And so this was what aggravated this person.
It was not the fact that I was female, it was the fact that I was an irritant.
And in a sense, Marcia, let me say that being married
has its advantages.
Because I have done this, I did this in Alabama, and I have been able to do this because if I lost my job, we always have my husband.
So I felt it's given me more independence.
That's good.
What have been some problems in your home life due to your career?
Or do you feel that there's been any?
I think that probably academia, better than some professional areas, fits better in with family life.
Certainly many women selected education early on because you could teach in elementary school and high school and still care for your family and that kind of thing.
And so it has worked well.
Only on a couple of occasions have I had some conflicts in terms of time.
And I taught in Michigan right up to a very short time before my daughter was born and went back.
about a month after.
So that fit very well in.
When I went to Alabama, I needed someone to care for my daughter while I was at school.
And the situation there was a little bit different than Michigan, so for a semester I had some arranging to do.

But it usually fit in very well, and children, young children, are pretty good as long as, if you're home, you can be working and writing after school, and you just have to water and feed children, and then they'll let you go ahead and do what you want to do.
So it's worked out real well.
What are some times in your life that you have felt discriminated against?
Marcia, just the situations on salary.
I really have not
I've had people who have treated me differently because I was a woman.
When I first came to Texas A&M, I was, I didn't realize that there were, I think there was one other woman full professor.
And I was suddenly on a lot of doctoral committees.
I would be

grad rep in committee after committee all over campus and I didn't realize that this was an effort of Dr. Quincy to begin to get a woman on a committee because all committees and every committee I served on I was the only woman and on the committees until people got to know me well

they would begin by asking me to ask questions first and usually on an exam the first questions go to the people within the department and certainly not to a grad rep and even when I was on a committee in another department because the student was minoring in sociology or something like this they would always turn to me first
Then after a while, in some of the departments where I appeared on committee after committee, I would say, look, no more of this.
And then after that, it was just like I was just another faculty member in their department.
So I'm not too difficult.
In the 1950s, women were viewed or stereotyped as being intuitive.
emotional, independent, while men were viewed as more intelligent, independent, and rational.
How do you feel about this?
Do you feel that this has changed over the past 30 years?
I guess so.
When I started graduate school at North Carolina,
I decided, because I had done so much research in the health area, in the sociology of health, that I would minor in public health.
And I worked under a man named Cecil Sheps, who is head of health affairs at the University of North Carolina now.
Very brilliant man.
And he had had, I was not interested in assistantship.
I had saved money, and I wanted to go through as quickly as possible.
It's not really the best way to go through graduate school.
It's much better to become a professor's assistant.
You learn more, and also the professor takes a greater interest in you, may help with employment and that kind of thing.
Dr. Sheps had had a woman assistant, and when I started coursework in the School of Public Health under him,
He was kind of shy of me at first.
And after about four weeks, he called me into his office and he said, will you accept an assistantship?
And at the end of four weeks, I began to realize how expensive graduate school was.
And so I told him I would.
And he said, I want to apologize for not offering you an assistantship when you came.
And he said, but I have just gone through two women assistants who, if I said one crossword or if I did not use all the niceties, they would fall apart and start to cry.
And he said, I just didn't think I could stand that again.
Sheps is the kind of person who, he didn't have a discriminatory bone in his body.
But what he was reacting to
were experiences that he had had.
He had never objected to having a woman.
It was just what he had experienced.
And there were a lot of women who role-played women and would use a lot of excuses for not doing this.
I think women do cry more readily than men.
but if you're going to work with men, you better be able to take it.
And this was not one of my problems.
I could take it well.
I might cry about other things.
If I get angry, I either cry or storm.
And the important thing is to storm, not cry.
But he had a bad experience, and so he reacted to that.
When he got to know me better, there was no problem.
But he did not like to
necessarily use all the nice.
If he wanted something done, he didn't always want to say please.
He didn't always want to say thank you.
It was understood by the way he treated you and by the confidence that he had in you.
And there are a lot of people who wanted all the rest.
Have your achievements or your being a professor and having a career made you feel less feminine?
No, no.
And I like being a woman.
I like it too.
Women tend to hold lower expectations of what they can accomplish.
Why do you feel that this is so?
And have you ever had feelings or felt that because you're a woman you can't accomplish certain achievements?
Marcia, I never did.
And I think some of this is not necessarily...
I don't know why this is true.
I guess I came from a family where women had always done things.
Now, my mother would say, well, she was robbed of certain opportunities.
But some of the opportunities, she was robbed by her mother.
But my mother, my grandmother had three factories.
My grandfather and his brothers manufactured jewelry.
Grandmother was off.
She had mesh bag factories.
I don't know whether you know what a mesh bag is.
The little evening bags.
Oh, yes.
Well, these were very, very popular early on in the century.
And my grandmother had three factories that manufactured them.
And my mother, if she had stayed in Providence, Rhode Island, could have done things like that.

She handled payroll as a young child, but she was very good at hat design, and she was offered a position in New York, and my grandmother wouldn't let her go because people thought of New York as being the big bad city.
And so Mother always felt that her career was stifled, you see, because of being a woman.
But it was her mother that really prevented her from doing this, not the chance to do it.
Have you ever felt isolated because you were a woman?
What do you mean by isolated?
Set apart from others or that, you know, in the department you were just kind of set aside because you were a woman?
No, not, except for the business, the exams.
I think a lot depends on how you role-play in your career and how...
I don't know.
There has been an awful lot of talk about the role of women and the problems of women.
And I think that after a while you can believe that all of this is true.
And I know for some women it has been true.
But it's also true
for some men.
For a long time, departments were really antsy about employing single men.

And so really lots of departments discriminated against single men because if you have a married man, you knew that he wasn't going to be off and running to another job if he didn't like the way things were going.
So there are all kinds of factors that affect both males and females in the job market.
That's interesting.
What effect did your parents have on you becoming a professor?
You said that they were real supportive.
Have they always been supportive in everything that you did?
Yes, they were always supportive.
Always supportive in education.

uh... always supported in giving me time to uh... to uh... to study uh... limiting limiting the uh... the kinds of things your a child is expected to do around the house when you have studies to do and all that but uh...
I think my father thought very strongly about education and so did my mother.
That's great.
How have you found that men and women are evaluated?
Are men and women evaluated differently in terms of their work and their achievements?
Oh, I think they can be.
And just because I have not had
difficult experiences doesn't mean that other women have not.
I think that there are positions where, as changes began to occur, women were in a sense isolated.
I had a friend at North Carolina who became the first woman executive with a major insurance company in Hartford, Connecticut.
and she could carry her own.
She was a very objective kind of person, but for a while, until they really got to know her, she was kind of isolated.
I think that you can interpret everything everyone says as being against a woman.
They say this to me because I'm a woman.
They may say these things if you are a man, and you've got to learn to differentiate.
And also, I think that there is a normalcy of behavior that sometimes women who are so
enamored of freedom and the feminist movement miss.
For example, I have had colleagues who will never discuss the fact that they're married.
In fact, you wouldn't even know they were married unless they happened to tell you.
I mean, unless something happened and it came to your attention.
They may have children, they will never discuss their children.
Now, males
Always do.
I mean, they'll talk about their children, they'll talk about their wife.
So that women who characteristically don't do this stand out as different.
I mean, with older faculty who always talk about their children and talk about this and talk about that, we all know about each other.
And for a woman to come on the scene and never do this,
Why do you think they don't talk about their children?
Well, what they say is that if I talk about this, then they're going to judge me as a woman.
Instead of seeing this as part of the behavior, as just human behavior, to talk about your family and so on.
And the interesting thing is most of these women have husbands who were really exceptional.
And I think it's a shame not
not to share your total life.
When you came to A&M, were there any women's organizations such as now?
No, no.
In fact, I was in this research program, and I was housed in a little temporary building where Blocker is.
And I just assumed there were tons of women all over.
And because we did not have a faculty club, the fact that we do not have a faculty club I think is very limiting.
I mean, a real faculty club, not a room in the bottom of or something like that, but a real faculty club.
Because in the faculty club, both male and female faculty are seen in informal occasions by each other.
And you do family kinds of things if there is a restaurant.
At the University of Alabama, we had a marvelous faculty club in an old mansion.
And we had a lovely dining room.
And the cook was a gourmet cook and published cookbooks.
And there were weddings there.
There were all kinds of things.
And people got to see each other in a variety of situations.
I just assumed there were women all over this campus.
And it was a big shock to me later to find out that there were not.
Now, I had signs, but I never read them right.
Because I had a lot of students who would come to see me, particularly male students, that were having problems and wanted to talk to someone.
And there were so few people to talk to.
for whatever reason, it always seems easier to talk to a woman.
So any students that I had in class very often would come to see me.
And some of their friends would often, you know, go see Dr. Shaffer.
And I really was not running a casework.
And I should have recognized the fact that we also didn't have adequate counseling
and that there were very few women on campus.
Have you ever been a member of NOW or any other women's organizations?
No, I've spoken to NOW on several occasions because one of my former students is very active in that organization.
What types of changes in favor of women have occurred at A&M besides the hiring of more women?
Well, I think the hiring of women has been important.
But with the growth of what I would distinguish as the new faculty,
Most of these people came from parts of the country where there were more women on the faculty than Texas A&M had previously had.
And so they accepted women without any difficulty.
And also the fact that a lot of people in academia have wives who have degrees or have advanced education in some area, and so they accept more readily
women in the marketplace than, let's say, in corporate America.

But it's interesting when you read or listen to people active in feminist organizations because they act as if women never held important positions in our society, and yet women have held important positions for a long, into the last century.
not as many, but certainly numbers of them.
And at this point in time, most women must be in the market place at the same time they are married, or else large numbers of families could not be middle class.
Do you feel that these women in the workforce have
obstacles to overcome?
I think there are obstacles.
I don't think there is a question that
